briefdescription.para: Build a CombinedMapping from the component mappings. This constructor should be used if the inverse jacobian of the first mapping, or the jacobian of the second mapping cannot be evaluated at the O-point.

parameterdescription.para: The parameter $ \varepsilon $ which determines when a point is close enough to the central O-point for linearisation to be required when calculating the inverse of the Jacobian. The Jacobian is linearised on $ r \in [0, \varepsilon] $.

briefdescription.para: Build a CombinedMapping from the component mappings. This constructor should be used if both mappings can be safely evaluated at all points in space.
Convert the argument coordinate to the equivalent result coordinate.

detaileddescription.para: For some computations, we need the complete Jacobian matrix or just the coefficients. This is calculated by combining the Jacobian matrices of the 2 curvilinear mappings.

para.formula: $ = J_{(x_{mid}, y_{mid})->(x_{out},y_{out})}J_{(x_{in}, y_{in})->(x_{mid}, y_{mid})} = J_F J_G $

detaileddescription.para: The Jacobians that are used for the calculation must be mappings from $ (x_{mid}, y_{mid}) $ so they can be calculated on the correct coordinate system.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the (i,j) component of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The (i,j) component of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the determinant of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The determinant of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the full inverse Jacobian matrix.

detaileddescription.para: If one of the mappings is singular then this function linearises the inverse Jacobian between the O-point and $ r = \varepsilon $. The inverse Jacobian at the O-point is calculated using the class InvJacobianOPoint in this case. The inverse Jacobian at a point where the matrices are not singular is calculated using non_singular_inverse_jacobian_matrix

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the inverse Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the (1,1) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The (1,1) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the (1,2) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The (1,2) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the (2,1) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The (2,1) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the (2,2) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The (2,2) coefficient of the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: Compute the determinant of the Jacobian matrix.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

simplesect.para: The determinant of the Jacobian matrix.

memberdef.definition: KOKKOS_INLINE_FUNCTION Mapping const & CombinedMapping< Mapping1, Mapping2 >::get
memberdef.name: get

briefdescription.para: Get access to one of the internal mappings.

parameterdescription.para: The mapping that we want to access.

simplesect.para: A constant reference to the internal mapping.

detaileddescription.para: Compute the inverse Jacobian matrix at a point where the matrices are not singular.
This is calculated by combining the Jacobian matrices of the 2 curvilinear mappings.
The Jacobians that are used for the calculation must be mappings from $ (x_{mid}, y_{mid}) $ so they can be calculated on the correct coordinate system.

parameterdescription.para: The coordinate where we evaluate the Jacobian matrix.

briefdescription.para: A class which describes a mapping which is constructed by combining two mappings. Let us denote Mapping1 as $ \mathcal{F} $ and Mapping2 as $ \mathcal{G} $ then this mapping represents: $ \mathcal{F} \circ \mathcal{G} $.

detaileddescription.para: There are therefore 3 domains in this calculation $ \Omega_{start} $, $ \Omega_{mid} $ and $ \Omega_{end} $ with $ \mathcal{F}(\Omega_{mid})\rightarrow\Omega_{end} $ and $ \mathcal{G}(\Omega_{start})\rightarrow\Omega_{mid} $
The functions in this mapping are defined on the coordinate system associated with the domain $ \Omega_{mid} $.
